author: scottctu

description.text:
The Printrbot Simple is a great little 3D printer that is easy to carry around (as long as you have something to hold onto).  The Carbon-Fiber Handle meets the requirement.  The parts for the Carbon-Fiber Handle were among the first things I printed after getting the Simple up and going.  The handle can also be made with an oak dowel, but the carbon-fiber tube is much stronger than wood, and it feels more secure when carrying the printer.  
The design has been updated (on 5 August 2013).  The original design fit the Beta Test version of the Simple.

• Print the handle parts (grouped into part 1 and part 2 to accommodate the size of the Simple printing bed).
  • Cut the 0.210 inch carbon-fiber tube into 3 pieces (2) 8.5 inch long and (1) 4.25 inch long.
  • Put 2 O-rings on each carbon-fiber tubes.
  • Insert the tubes into the printed parts.
  • Drill 1/32 inch holes through printed-parts-with-tubes for pinning the tubes with nails.
  • Cut nails to .5 inch (if necessary) and push them through printed-parts-with-tubes using pliers
  • Cover the nails with O-rings to keep them in place (and to complete handle assembly).
  • Locate the handle on the Printrbot Simple and drill holes for the screws.
  • Attach the handle with screws
  • Enjoy!
    • Materials
    (4) Printed parts
    (4) O-rings (ID = 7/16 inch)
    (6) #2 x .5 inch brass screws
    (6) #19 x .5 inch wire nails (or cut longer nails)
    (1) 0.210 inch carbon fiber tube from Amazon.com cut into (2) 8.5 inch pieces and (1) 4.25 inch piece Note:
    Sometimes printed parts split along the grain, and the O-rings alleviate this worry. Confession:
    I printed my Carbon-Fiber Handle parts in ABS on my Printrbot LC because I wanted to safely handle my Simple from the beginning.

comments.text: I have updated the design to fit the final version of the Simple, and the STL files sliced OK for me.

description.text: A small foot that can clip onto the 6mm bars of a Mini-Mendel/Huxley RepRap printer. UPDATE 5.6.11: I should warn that I created these feet before constructing the Z axis, and it may be the case that these feet are too short with all the gears and mechanisms under the Z rods. At the moment there are a few millimeters clearance, but I have not yet installed the motors or Z rods completely. I will update this description once I complete the build. UPDATE 11.6.11: If the feet are placed on the lowermost bar (front and back) then there is plenty of room for the Z axis. I've attached some photos showing this. This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/p/acc097b350c8941b

I found that it will print fine with zero infill with 0.4 Thickness and 0.5 W/T Ratio.  Otherwise the the infill motion will vibrate the printer quite a bit.  Your mileage may vary.
Pressing the still-warm piece around the metal rod makes for a nice, tight fit.

author: jjpj

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jsCGDf4fIVJ

Here's a more polished, production-ready update to the domekit 3d-printable geodesic connector system. We refactored the central hub to feature a rounded edge and use less material. The strutcaps are shorter while being more durable, and include an integrated thumbscrew (with captive nut) that locks the strut to the node. This makes the structure easier to assemble, because you're not trying to snap the balls into the sockets â€” just slide the strut into the shaft and turn the screw.
    • please visit http://domekit.cc for more details

There are two types of hubs, a 5- and 6-way, and one type of strutcap that will snap into the sockets on either. A completed connector must have all of it's sockets filled with strutcaps in order to have proper tension. Start by printing off a 6-way hub and 6 strutcaps. See if you can snap all of the 'caps into the hub. The last one might take some force; you can push down against a table for some leverage. You're looking to get the tightest fit possible whilst still retaining a good range of motion. It should be difficult to get them out once you've put them all in.  We suggest trying to adapt the hubs to fit the strutcaps, either by scaling it using replicatorG or tuning your skeinforge settings. If all else fails, jump into the hub.scad file and tweak the expansion_factor variable.
The strutcaps have a hole that should accept an M3 nut. A 10mm M3 bolt should pass through the side of the connector, through the nut, and push against the strut when tightened. The strutcap shafts are designed to work with 3/8" / 10mm strut poles.
A 2V icosahedron requires 26 connectors (20 x 6-way, 6 x 5-way) for a total of 176 parts. A 3V 5/9 requires 61 connectors (55 x 6-way, 6 x 5-way) for a total of 421 parts. The 6-way connectors against the bottom of the sphere are techically 4-way connections, but you can fold up two of the strut caps to make a flat-bottomed connector. Sure, we could have made a separate 4-way connector, but doing so would have increased the inventory of parts you'll need to keep track of.

title: Servo driven ball raced & geared pan/tilt

description.text: Pan tilt mechanism with ball raced pan platform & geared tilt for higher torque.

This pan tilt was made to be the base for my robot head (coming soon)
I needed a stable base with little play & a strong tilt.
I used 6mm airsoft balls for the bearings, but any 6mm ball will do.

All the parts for the tilt mechanism are printed in one file.
The servo base is printed by itself.

I have printed the parts in the orientation that is in the file.
I used an Up2 printer on fine with 0.15mm layer height.

Bearings for the tilt pivot are : MR106 (10 x 6 x 3mm)

Servo for tilt is this one:

http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__45606__Corona_939MG_Digital_Metal_Gear_Servo_2_7kg_12_5g_0_13sec_AUS_Warehouse_.html

Servo for pan is this one:

http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__24578__Turnigy_TGY_4409MD_Metal_Gear_Digital_Servo_9_45kg_0_11sec_44g.html

To assemble the top plate/tilt mechanism:

Glue servo mounts to top pan plate. They are a tight fit so acetone can be used as the adhesive.

Glue the mounting plate to the gear/shaft assembly, being careful to place the holes in the mount where you want them & ensuring that the mount is aligned with the flat section of the gear on the opposite end of the shaft.

I placed the shaft on a flat surface with the flat of the gear against the bench & used this to align the other plate while gluing.

Press the bearings into the upright supports.
Place the gear/shaft assembly between the upright supports.

Glue the upright support without screw holes into the top pan plate, using the shaft as an alignment spacer. Screw the other upright into place using screws no longer than 8mm. This upright is made to be removable for disassembly. Don't glue it in!!!! Screws longer than 8mm will damage the bearing surface on the other side.

I held all this together with rubber bands until the glue was well dried.

While glue is drying, paint a small amount of acetone into the pinion & allow the ABS to soften. Place the pinion onto the tilt servo drive & push it home. The acetone softens the plastic and it takes the shape of the splines in the servo drive. Screw the pinion down till its fully home & check pinion is square with the servo.

Once glue is well dried, remove the screwed on upright from the top plate & mount the servo. Ensure servo is centred & also that the tilt plate is in the position you want it when the pinion gear meshes.

Screw servo into place, making sure pinion has meshed fully with the shaft gear. Use screws no longer than 8mm. The servo I used had 2 small lugs on each mounting tab that I had to remove to ensure a flat mounting surface.

Once servo is mounted, replace upright & screw into place.

Once assembled, the shaft/gear can be removed by:

  1. Removing the screwed in upright.
  2. Removing the servo/pinion assembly
  3. Rotating the gear 180 degrees. It will catch slightly at the bottom, but will turn.
  4. The shaft can then be slipped out of the bearing in the glued upright.

The lower servo mount is fairly straight forward.

The tilt plate will need to be disassembled to access the four screws that hold the upper plate on.

Screw the circular servo drive onto the upper plate using four screws. The recess in the upper plate will hold the drive concentric.

Screw the servo into place in the lower plate.

Once servo is mounted, insert the bearings (I forgot to count how many there are....) into the lower plate.

Place the top plate over the lower one, lining up the lower servo drive as you do.

Use the servo drive fixing screw to pull the top plate down onto the servo drive spline & bearings.

Be careful not to over tighten the screw or there will be too much load on the servo.

Just tight enough to remove all slop is all that is required. You may need a small amount of threadlocker to prevent screw from coming loose.

I hope these instructions are adequate.
If anyone prints one of these, I'd love to see it!

Video at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1ZG92MYnioA

I'd also like to thank the following contributors:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73555 - for giving me the idea to use airsoft bearings.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:507974 - for his excellent cylindrical gear SCAD code, without which, this project would not have been as easy.

Thank you gents!

title: NACA Airfoils - 4 digit fully parametric OpenSCAD library

description.text:
Are you playing around with airfoils? Better have a fast airfoil data generator at hand. I found some code doing airfoils in this forum, but that wasn't flexible enough as it didn't take advantage of the new vector features of OpenSCAD 2015.
So I coded my own little library to always have a fully customizable 4 digit NACA airfoil data generator at hand.

What you get

  • a fully parametric library
  • a bunch of usage examples
  • help functionality
  • well documented code (but very tough in the core part)

In my next post I'll show how to do objects that sweep smoothly between different airfoil types being freely shifted and rotated in 3D space. Stay tuned.

comments.text: This is well done! I'm just having issues with the points. The points produced by this code don't reflect the same points given by a NACA point generator. Does this have something to do with "sign(b)" in your thickness distribution equation? The airfoils appear to have higher camber than normal.

comments.text: I didn't comprehend the issue, because my local copy of this lib showed correct behavior. Now I found out that it did not match the uploaded version. I uploaded the corrected version now. Sorry ...
comments.author: dweaver123

comments.text:
Actually people use different parametrizations for the thickness distribution. I think I took mine from this document
https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19970008124.pdf (see pg. 3, left)
You'll find the parameters in the line
comments.author: dweaver123

comments.text: Yeah it looks to me like the camber is incorrect as well. In the NACA(naca) function you take the first digit and divide it by 10 to get the max camber %. That would make a 2412 airfoil have a 20% camber. It should be a 2% camber. The airfoil([]) calls also specify 20% camber when called with [0.2, x, x]. If you compare what the library generates for a 2412 to one from Airfoil Tools you'll see the camber is 10x what it should be in the library.
comments.author: Parkinbot

comments.text: Well, I don't think so. The function NACA converts conventional values like 2412 into a vector. Try
comments.author: CapnBry

This is just me learning my new toy.

The center wheel gave me a bit of hassle while printing so I printed on masking tape besides the kapton and cool before moving so it didn't smear .
Each Cabin needs to be folded correctly. I used a dimmed soldering iron (Turn the dimmer to just the right heat for melting but not smoke). The .81mm music wire holds the cabs to the center wheel then a bolt or piece of 1/8" dowel holds the ferris wheel to the a frame. the a frame gets glued at the feet to the bottom peice(or you could meltstick with the soldering iron)
The gondula needs no bending/weilding and is probably the best bet but it will not print correctly on my prusa(I still dont know all the ins and outs), so I have to go with folding. Also my machine has a hidden glitch that it stops printing and needs to be reset.
The path I recommend to follow would be with the 28 ferris wheel design using the split gondula or the 14 using the cabin.

title: Tiny CNC XY gear with fitting and pen arm

description.text:
Parts to improve on the Tiny CNC, a pen arm that snaps onto the Z axis and an XY gear that has an indent where the motor can fit better. This will add one piece and replace the XY gear. Print one pen arm and two XY gears. Get the remaining pieces and remaining instructions from the original.

XYGearNew.stl is more compatible with a micro-servo 9g, which is what is used in the tinyCNC. The other Plotter XY Gear file is for bigger servos. It works great. Use the four arm piece that comes with the motor, screw it in, and make great prints!

the male plugs on the pen holder go in the holes on the Z-axis. Put a little dot of superglue in to hold them tight and forever. Print two, put on on the top of the Z axis and the other on the bottom.

SendingSerial004 is a processing sketch where you can easily copy-paste your filename. I had trouble with SendingSerial003.
http://plotterbot.com/tiny-cnc/challenges-entered/drawing-robot-afron-ultra-affordable-educational-robot-2013-design-challenge-entry/tinycnc-drawing-robot-software-user-guide/

comments.text:
Cool! I was working on a similar kind of XY gear, but I think yours is better. :)
Your pen holder seems to have two male plugs on it - where do those go?
And, last but not least, do you have any videos of your bot in action?
I'd love to see it!
MakerBlock
comments.author: MakerBlock

comments.text: The male plugs go in the holes on the Z-axis.
comments.author: MakerBlock

comments.text: Oooooooh, okay.  You know, you might be better off just redesigning the Z axis.  The reason I designed the Z axis with those holes was that they were a quick and dirty way to be able to attach a pen via zip ties, rubber bands, tape, wire, or whatever I had on hand.  There's nothing special about those holes or their sizes at all.
comments.author: aevictory

comments.text:
I made it to plug in to the existing Z axis for ease of printing - otherwise it would need support. I think Zmax and Zmin are reversed in the arduino programs. I am going a little nuts trying to get the gcode to do... anything. First, when the Zmax and Zmin were reversed, it drew what was supposed to be pen up and didn't draw what was supposed to be pen down. I got pretty close to a hello world, just the parts between the letters. Now something's screwed up and it seems to draw random lines. I know you have all of your processing and arduino sketches on your blog, could you upload your most current (and working) versions either here or to github? That would be really helpful.
Thanks for the excellent design. Now it's just the software...
I also added a AA battery on the platform with double stick tape a a counterweight so that when the y-axis fully extends it doesn't tip over and pull the x-axis out of the rack.

title: Customizable X-Carriage screw holes Geeetech Based

description.text:
This is also another customizable screw hole but based on geeetech x-carriage design because the difference between vanilla or the rest of the design and geeetech; geeetech uss a 45mm lm8uu while most 3d printer uses 25mm lm8uu.

Unless you want to use this with a printable bushing can be found here which is nice, might be a good idea (I never tried these bushings yet) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:91389

This item is for those who are using geeetech 45mm lm8uu but with the ability to change the screw hole profile without the need to change the lm8uu just because the other x-carriage uses better or different screw hole profile.

The belt slit also improved to have slightly wider slit for easy insertion, slanted slit opening as well as flat teeth at the bottom part where the belt supposed to be looped around the screw holes

However, the part are not tested by me yet especially the belt slit on the loop area in between the edge of each sides (where every geeetech owner would have problem inserting belt there)

Either download the stl parts or the zip

zip file contain stock geeetech x carriage, script and another 2 finished stl. The scad script needs geeetech stock file in order for you to render the finished product

Type

  • 1 is vanilla, default is geeetech

title: 'Maker Clips'... Paper Clips / Mini Bookmarks for MakerBot users

description.text:
Very simple but smart little paper clips with the MakerBot logo designed in. Unlike metal paper clips these, when printed near to solid, they are springy so flex to accommodate from 1 to 15 sheets of standard copy paper.

Why "1" sheet... because they work with a single sheet you can use them as a Mini Bookmark as well as a paper clip.

Just another 3D printed alternative for an everyday item.

As this is a fairly fine print I recommend printing at least 2-up so the print gets a chance to rest/solidify between layers. This may be beneficial on some printers.

Note: If you like this check out all my other designs!
On a Replicator 2 these print really well 2-up with Raft, 0.20mm (Std. resolution, 3 shells and 75% infill... this makes them almost solid so they are springy and reasonably durable.

title: Belt clip for a popular UHF handheld radio model

description.text:
This is designed to be a drop-in replacement belt clip for a well known name brand radio. It has most aspects of the original - including the overall curve and retaining stops underneath. You need to print this sideways (on it's side) to get the required bending strength. I printed in black ABS (and white) and the part happily bends at least as much as the original without snapping.
Photo shows 2 3d prints (lower) and 2 originals (upper, one snapped).
Dont forget to print this on its long side for bending strength.

author: jjcotton

title: Debbie's Mophie Juicebox Air Charging Stand

description.text: This is a charging stand for my wife's Juice Box Air. It uses a generic usb mini cable which is fed up into the stand through an access port and then seated into a hole positioned for this case. My larger Mophie case does not fit, as this was designed for her case only. You can, of course, get Mophie's charger which fits all their cases perfectly. This was a fun exercise and the Chocolatey Brown ABS makes my mouth water. The STL file does not include the "D".

The modeling was accomplished using the Onshape.com web based CAD program. If you would like to modify it for your own, leave a comment and I will share the project via their public lists. It was printed in ABS on my UP! Plus 2 printer. Portions of this design are specific to the usb cord I had handy. Therefore, your mileage may vary based on the shape and size of your usb plug. I used a slender bit of double sided foam tape to secure the plug into its bed. Two machine screws hold the base and cord in place.

author: petermac2

description.text:
This mini filament reel is for small amounts of filament and prints easily on a 150x150 bed. Part (a) holds the filament and part (b) is the end cap. You can print part (a) complete to get a 3cm width reel or stop it at any point. My photo is of a reel that I stopped after 2cm, it's holding about 10-15m of filament.

Features: 80mm diameter cylinder to wind the filament which prevents bruising; 37mm centre hole to give an easy fit without wobbling; filament hole at the centre to get the winding started; filament hole at the rim to lock it when fully wound (the spokes are also good for locking the end of the filament.

The freecad source is also included in case you want to tweak sizes etc. Note that I passed the freecad exported stl through the fixer at netfabb otherwise Slic3r (v1.2.9) missed out the central spokes for some reason.

I made this with two perimeters and two solid layers with 25% infill. It's worth setting your extrusion width to .5mm as that gives exact dimensions for the two cylinders at the centre of the reel which have 1.5mm thick walls.

Once you've printed the two parts you will need to sand off any imperfections before pushing together. The fit will be tight enough without glue etc.

comments.text:
Perfect for when big spools are running out and you want to save up some room!
I must have at least 5 of them already!

comments.author: UnfortunateFish

comments.text: Yes that's what I use it for. The full size reels are just too cumbersome for 20m or so of filament.

Inspired from this
http://sheerwind.com/technology/how-does-it-work

searching for a proper utilization, I found that it can be helpful for wind speed measuring, using a wind sensor. Additional sensors like temperature or humidity can be attached creating a weather station.

https://moderndevice.com/product/wind-sensor-rev-p/

http://moderndevice.com/product/sht21-humidity-and-temp-sensor/

The advantage to this solution is that it captures the wind no matter where the wind blows, because when beating it may change direction.

Wind catcher diameter is about 120 mm.
Long tube length 130 mm
Middle tube length 70 mm (for sensors purpose)
Short tube length 30 mm

comments.text: The corner should be a little bigger. That is a little to small.

comments.text: Bigger in diameter or length? What about tube, do you share  idea of making it smaller ?
comments.author: RikhardKarlsson

comments.text: The corner's diameter was a little to small, it had a gap when installing it. It needs about 8mm more in circumference. I printed this with ABS, and it shrinks (But I think everyone uses ABS).

Hi, I've added a support for tube and a second version of it.
I've measured the corner diameters and they are correct 50, 54 and 60 mm.
The 2 sections for a better printing were made with slic3r, so maybe here there appeared some gaps.

Using the following options: image_file = lithopane20130516-17909-g4bs93-0.dat
hole_diameter = 5
layer_height = 0.1
number_of_layers = 19
A telescope I made for my daughter, she wanted it 'rainbow' so I printed each piece in a different colour.

Print one of each piece. I printed these at 0.2mm layer depth. The walls are 1mm wide, which on my printer is 2 walls and no fill **looking at the images, you may need to flip the eyepiece so you can print it without support.

You will also need two pieces of clear perspex, one at 65mm diameter and one of 30mm diameter. I am not 100% sure but I think this would actually work as a telescope with some magnifying lenses (it is a future job to find out).

To put together:

Place the 65mm perspex in the 'end' of the telescope, stack pieces 1 through 6 in each other and then place on the 'end' piece. Part 1 should fit snugly in to the end piece and you can glue (I used acetone) this in once you are sure that you have it right.

Then place the 30mm perspex in the eyepiece, extend the telescope and give it a bit of twist so that it does not collapse, then glue (again I used acetone) the eyepiece to the end of piece 6.

Once the glue has dried you can go ahead, get your parrot on your shoulder start talking pirate speak and be ultra cool with your own custom printed telescope. A slight twist and pull will ensure that it doesn't collapse on you while you are trying to look through it and a good whack will collapse it when you are ready.

author: ozanbdr

title: Door Lion Wall Hanger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I found another door lion that was 3D scanned. I turned it into a model you can hang on the wall on a nail or screw. If you like this one, I have more of these on Thingiverse!

I used MeshMixer, SketchUp and VisCAM to make this. I deleted some parts of the scan (surrounding area) and made it solid so it can be 3D printed. I cut out the middle circle and head but found it too thin so I added an outer ring for more body.

The original scan is here, thanks for making the scan! http://www.123dapp.com/catch/door/3938679

http://www.3dwp.nl

Grey Warden Griffon pendant! The detail work is still too fine for me to do anything smaller than a silver dollar ish size, but if you have an amazing printer, go for it!

Also excuse my crappy camera phone.

This is my first attempt at a Grey Warden pendant/key chain whatever. I originally just simplified one of the banners in Gimp, tinkered with it as an SVG in Inkscape and finally finished it in Tinkercad.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gPV8vzlBmEa.

comments.author: Digbydig

title: Toothbrush Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A practical flower pot shaped accessory! Hold toothbrushes, pencils, scissors, use as an ashtray, or come up with your own unique function. There is about 11 cubic in. of volume; based on what other people have posted for cost that should be around $3.xx in material. This is a 2 piece design, allowing the user to unscrew the top and clean or get access to the insides with a simple 1/4 turn. The connection was influenced by Wizard23's idea for a Screw-able jewelry box ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:413 ), which I was able to see in person and it works beautifully. Be careful with the top because there is an extra mechanical advantage since the top is wider, so it should take less force to unscrew. I dont have a makerbot, so I designed this conservatively. However, I took a couple printing risks with the details at the very bottom and very top. I think it should print based on my experience with other 3d printers, so I am very excited to see the Thingiverse community bring it to life. Please send me your feedback! I will update the files if there are reports of problems or someone wants a specific change.

Print out the top and the bottom stl files so that the threaded features sit at the top and are the last thing to be printed.  If there are settings to print out a honeycomb pattern in the thick sections, you will save material.
ENJOY!

This platform mounts directly to the front (or rear) bed support for the Robo3d. It uses the existing holes to attach and has a hole large enough to fit a ¼ x 20 tripod screw. Since almost all camera and webcams can be mounted on a tripod this will accept nearly all cameras made.

The screws to hold this platform in place are M4. Replace the existing M4 screw that is used to tension the Y Axis belt with one that is 10 mm longer.

Print this out with a minimum of 3 perimeters and 20% infill to make it stiff enough to prevent shaking. Once complete remove the exiting M4 screw holding the Y Axis tension block, use a screw that is 10 mm longer and replace the tension block and new screw in left hole. Using a M4 x 15 or 16 mm screw and nut on the opposite side affix it through the remaining mounting hole.

Print this upside-down It can be printed without any support material.

IGES and STEP Source files included if you want to remix this model.

author: Chris6S

description.text: Many old radios use the long obsolete - and expensive - WD-11 tube. This base uses 3 pieces of 3/16" brass tube and a piece of 1/8" brass tube for pins. A CK5676 tube is soldered into the pins with a 22 ohm resistor across the filament to create the proper current draw http://www.vcomp.co.uk/tech_tips/wd11/wd11.htm. A cut-off piece of 1" diameter test tube can be inverted over the 5676 tube to resemble the original WD-11.
I uses Cura and sliced it at .2mm layer height. Use ABS, due to the lower melting point of PLA (vacuum tubes generate HEAT).

title: Arthritis Assist - Button Assist, Zipper Pull, Key Assist, and Bag Handle

description.text:
I created these for a contest last September (2014) and thought I would share them here too. I have printed and tested them and they seem to work pretty well. The zipper pull took many iterations to get to a functional state. If you use strong material with 100% fill it will last a long time.

You can see a video of all the devices here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IK19hcsD0wQ

comments.text: Thank you! the button assist will come in handy for me. After 30+ years playing guitar tying fishing knots and fiddling with tiny electronics you would think my dexterity would be out of this world and at one point it was, I could easily tie knots with one hand using just my fingers. Time is catching up with me and at 51 I'm finding just buttoning my shirt to be a chore I'm printing the device as I type this.

title: Overlook maze from The Shining as a switch plate.

I needed to spend time on something other than designing the wind powered rock tumbler so I made this. Perfect for the Kubrick fan on your list. Check out my other designs for interesting odd things.
Printed with support material on. PLA on cold glass with gluestick.

The Wind Spinner will work on a flat hard surface where there is plenty of wind. The panels on the wind catcher will catch the wind and rotate it on its 8 wheels.

1. Print one wind catcher and one base
  2. Print 8 wheels and axles
  3. Glue the bottom of the wind catcher stick to the center of the base
  4. Put the axles through the holes on the base and attach with hot glue, poly cement, etc.
  5. Slide the wheels on the axle and put a dab of hot glue on the end to prevent it from coming off.
  6. Put on hard surface, create some wind and watch it spin!

comments.text: pretty cool and principle it should work, but from a physics standpoint, when the wind blows, it will torque the lever arm , which is the shaft halding the vanes to the bottom bearing holder, and the whole assembly will go down on it's knickers .. therefore, it is required to have a bearing race AND some external weight(anchor) affixed to the bottom of said bearing race !
comments.author: freNRG

comments.text: And where would I put the bearing race? Wouldn't it just prevent the rotation of the vanes to reach the bottom rotating piece?

Ah, the humble goof plug. No matter how many bags of these I buy, they are never to be found in my irrigation repair kit when I need one. With the current water shortages and neighbors encouraged to rat each other out at the slightest spurt, I need to stay on top of the inevitable weed-whacker mishaps.
This prints best in batches of 12 or more. Very quick to print. These should fit the standard 1/2" or 5/8" drip irrigation tubing with holes punched in it (common US size). They require a bit of force to push in the holes but will stay in against pressure.
You use these when you no longer need a hole punched in your feed line and want to close it up. Usually the tricky part is getting the broken-off barb out of the hole - needle-nose pliers recommended.

title: Prototype Wallace Eckstruder fan mount V1 and 2

description.text:
I had to make a ducted fan mount that fit my Wallace G1, or really any printer using my Wallace edition Eckstruder.

This is only verified to work with an actual J-head hot-end. (Provided they didn't get longer or shorter since my last one. )

The first one is a simple one piece print with no support. However, it kept running into my bed clips.

V2 is a 3 part glue together affair. Seems to be working well. Still testing.

I will upload scad file when I'm happy with it.

Print X2 version. All three parts.

Use Acetone or favourite glue to attach arms to body. Vents pointing in.

Attach 40mm fan.

mount on Wallace Eckstruder fan mount holes.

Test.

Diamond Hotend mounts for Makerbot Replicator / Wanhao Duplicator 4 and possibly other clones.

Updated X-carriage and cooling shield to ver. 3. Files now include "Wanhao ver3.factory" which is the Simplify3D file which include recommended support structure as shown on the picture.

You need a mag holder for your G36 ? You have a tactical vest with molle attach ?

This thing is for you !

Warning : tested with airsoft mag, but not tested with real mag.

You'll need :

  • (2x) m3 screws (20x3mm)
  • (2x) m3 nuts
  • a realy strong elastic (I used a flexible rope and a tensioner instead)
  • (2x) strap (20cmx20mm)

And of course a G36 mag and a molle vest.

Warning : For tightly holding the mag and do not lose it, you'll need a very strong and almost inflexible elastic !

author: sheridansummerstem

description.text: This is the MakerSlide extrusion by Bart Dring http://www.thingiverse.com/bdring from http://www.makerslide.com/. MakerSlide is a V rail integrated into a standard aluminum extrusion profile. It's going to make designing light-duty CNC systems easier and more affordable. I've just put the design in a few different formats, so we can start to use it in free software. OpenSCAD + DXF makerslide_extrusion_profile.dxf : The first step was to bring the published DXF into Blender, convert into millimeters (1 Blender unit == 1 mm), and place it at the origin in a way that will be easy to work with when trying to do translate() calculations in your head, for OpenSCAD. makerslide.scad : This OpenSCAD script just demonstrates using the built-in DXF import-and-extrude function, wrapped in a module, so you can start using makerslide(h) whenever you need to stick a linear slide somewhere. (Make sure makerslide_extrusion_profile.dxf is in the same directory as the OpenSCAD script.) vwheel.scad : model of the delrin V wheel from the drawings for bdring's version 2.0 laser http://www.buildlog.net/sm_laser/drawings.html Blender makerslide_2D.blend : This is the Blender file I used to make the DXF. (Though I changed the layer name in the DXF source to "makerslide".) makerslide_3D.blend : 100mm extrusion as a mesh in Blender. vwheel.blend : delrin V wheel, with bearing, as mesh in Blender. Sketchup makerslide_100mm.skp : 100mm extrusion and one v wheel in Sketchup. There is another "dynamic" (parametric length) version of this by Meduza done in Sketchup Pro. Find it in the Sketchup 3D Warehouse, here: http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=220018fa83b2ba2f52f05c121726c97c ... but no wheel. So check Meduza's model to see if it's easier to work with, and then get the wheel out of my model.

remixed_from.author: KwikFiVo
remixed_from.title: Prusa 10" i3v Y-Axis End Plate with Belt Tensioner

title: Remix of Makerfarm i3v Y-Axis End Plate for 8", 10" & 12" with Belt Tensioner

description.text:
Update 2/3/2016 Major Rework The dimension for the 8" i3v should be correct now since I received the dimensions from Colin Farrer the creator of the Makerfarm i3v series. I also changed the way the ledges work so I could vary the heights which should make it stronger for the 12" i3v as well as the 10"

In the openscad file the following variables you may want to change.
First set the variable i3v to the size machine you have, either 8, 10 or 12
i3v = 10;

//Length of Ledge along the top before it slopes down
Ldg_Len = 22;

//Height of the ledge on the top side
//I used 20 for the 8, 10 & 12"
//You might want to go to 24 on the 12"
//You might want to use 14 or less for the 8"
Ldg_Ht_Top = 20;

//20 is the maximum here before part of gets cut
//for Belt Tensioner add on
Ldg_Ht_Bot = 20;

Update 12/24/2015 Idler Insert Jig I added a jig to make it easier to insert the M5x30mm bolt to attach the idler pulley. Since it is a small footprint on the printbed, I used a 6mm brim to keep it stuck. I am using F695zz Mini Metal Double Shielded Flanged Ball Bearings (5mm13mm4mm) from Ebay

This is a modification of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:613602 for the makerfarm i3v 10". I modified this design so it should fit the 8", 10" or 12" i3v. I have been using the previous design for several months without any problems & decided to update it to add a little more structural support with ledges that have worked well in my other designs. The big change is of course being able to use this on a 8", 10" or 12" i3v. I also added a little more plastic to the belt tensioner although that has been working quite well for a few months. I included the openscad file for the Y-Axis Endplate & the Belt Tensioner. The openscad file uses the included dxf file for the 8", 10" or 12" versions. I used the file https://github.com/DonKahones/MakerFarm-Prusa-i3v-12-Inch to get the hole pattern spacing for the 12" i3v, then subtracted 2" to get the 10" & 4" to get the 8". I have not tested the 8" or the 12", but feel they should both work since the 10" version works perfectly.

I had some trouble getting the washers on both sides of the bearings, but found the trick of holding them together & squeezing the plastic flange together so it was a tight fit as I put them in place before getting the bolt through them. I had to adjust the eccentric nuts on the y-carriage & relevel the bed after replacing this part.

I printed the 10" version using PETG plastic with .5 rectilinear infill density & .2 layer height & added ears to the corners. It took 3 hours 59 minutes to print. I printed both parts before at .2 infill without any problems, but decided to use more infill this time.

If you install this part, while printing something on your printer, put your finger on the bottom right or left leg like shown in one of the photos & feel how much less vibration is there relative to other parts of this plastic part like the middle or lower part of the Z frame. My printer is pretty quiet as it is, but seemed even quieter after I installed this part. I am wondering if that Z design is helping to deflect the vibration.

I printed this the 1st time at45 degs to fit on the build plate, but fit quite well horizontally along the X -axis.

Follow the instructions from the original part http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:613602

comments.text: Has anyone tried the 12 inch and confirmed it worked? My end plate for the 12" is bowing a lot and is starting to mess with my prints.
comments.author: cye604

comments.text: This guy made a version for the 12" because he said it flexed too much on his 12" i3v. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:910837 His version does not have the tensioner that I remixed from this design. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:613602 Maybe I will revisit making this design stronger in the next month. I need to take it apart soon to replace the idler bearings with these that have flanges that I found. http://www.ebay.com/itm/10-x-F695zz-Mini-Metal-Double-Shielded-Flanged-Ball-Bearings-5mm-13mm-4mm-/141339438982?hash=item20e87caf86:g:BFAAAOSwDk5Tt1~Y
comments.author: cye604

comments.text: 8" is too small, Not quite wide enough to mount to my printer! Oh well
comments.author: cybercorey

comments.text: Sorry, but not having an 8" version or dxf files of the wood parts I am really only guessing.  I used the 12" version to make the 10" spacing by subtracting 2", so it seemed reasonable that subtracting another 2" would make the 8" version.  Is it the hole pattern that is off?  If you can give me either the center line spacing, outside to outside or inside to inside Alum. extrusion spacing I can correct that.
comments.author: cybercorey

comments.text: I measured 5 15/16", I don't think it's metric. I too printed the 8" version and it's just a bit too small. Really looking forward to the corrected part, the one I printed looks awesome!
comments.author: GeoDave

comments.text: I am working on redesigning the Back Y-axis Plate  for the three different i3v's & was able to get that dimension from Colin.  He says it is 148.8mm between the center lines of the V-Slot.  Your 5 15/16" is 150.81mm which is pretty close to what he says.  When I finish the back plate, I will fix the 8" version of this design.  On the front Y-axis plate, I am also making the ledges a little taller in the middle to make it stronger.  Thanks for the input.  I started a build  thread for that design on the 3dprintboard:
comments.author: halber_mensch

comments.text: Excellent! Thanks for putting this out there, I can't wait to print it!
comments.author: GeoDave

comments.text:
I updated this and it should work on the 8" version. See the Update in the description for info on adjusting variables to your liking. If you do not want to adjust anything in the openscad file,
Just print:
Y-axis_IdlerEndplate_8inch_Rev34_repaired.stl
Y-axis_Idler_BeltTensioner_rev1.stl (This is the same part as was always used)
IdlerInsertJig_rev2.stl (This helps to hold the bearings in place while installing idler bolt)
comments.author: halber_mensch

comments.text: Unfortunately my first attempt delaminated at the tensioner fork when I tried to test the fit. I was doing 100% infill, is that what you'd suggest or do you use Colin's default .4 density honeycomb? Some buttressing on those forks might be desirable, I might have a go at the scad sometime and add that in.
comments.author: GeoDave

comments.text: I have never used 100% except for test cube. In the past I have used 50% rectangular infill.  Since switching to Sli3r 1.2.9, I am using 50% 3d Honeycomb & Octagram spiral for the Top & Bottom.  The Octagram gives it a nice pattern for the front part on the machine.  I have used 70% infill on some of the parts for the Mostly Printed CNC project.  What type of plastic are you using? I use either PLA or PETG.  All the newer plastic parts on my printer I am using PETG.
comments.author: halber_mensch

comments.text: I've been using ABS only thus far. I reprinted with the head up to 130C from 125C and used a 40% infill (I forget which kind I chose). The delamination was not so bad, but it did try to break again when I test fit the tensioner. This time rather than let it split the whole way I hit the cracked joint with the heat gun and it healed back up. I'm now back up and printing a J1772 holster.
comments.author: GeoDave

comments.text:
You might could redesign the belt tensioner to take out the 10mm there. 10mm seems like a lot to give up on an 8" bed. That was designed by someone else & was for the 10". You might also want to try printing with PETG plastic. I have been printing all my replacement parts on the printer with it, even the X-carriage. I might print the extruder at some point with it.
Thanks for testing the design and giving your feed back.
comments.author: halber_mensch

comments.text: Yeah PETG is next on my list. As far as the missing bed space goes, I was going to consider spending $12 on longer extrusions. The only other idea I had was to add height to the plate at the extrusion attachment points so the whole tensioner assembly and frame front are backed out away from the frame further.
comments.author: GeoDave

comments.text: Would it be possible to cut out the top part of theY-axis_Idler_BeltTensioner_rev1.stl to give you the clearance which would leave that open at the top.  You could also add some width to the bottom of it to give it more structure if that makes it too flimsy.  If it still hits the Y-axis endplate, you should be able to cut part of the top of that off also.  I am not sure any of that will work, but seems worth trying.
comments.author: halber_mensch

comments.text: I'll have a go at it sometime in the near future and let you know what I find. I need to move on and get XY plane normal correction (AKA bed auto leveling) working, I'm really getting tired of having to re-adjust the bed every time I leave the printer idle for a few days ;)
comments.author: GeoDave

comments.text:
I took a look at the belt tensioner & made an open end version. Take at look at this file:
BeltTensionerOpenEnd_Rev1_repaired.stl
I uploaded here & see if that might help your problem of loosing the 1/2"
comments.author: halber_mensch

comments.text: That might do it. I'm using http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:796250 to anchor my belt, and the open end may allow the anchor to pass through enough to gain some space back. I'll print that out this weekend and let you know how it works.
comments.author: GeoDave

comments.text:
I redesigned the back Y-Axis plate also if you want to try that one on the 8". It works quite well on the 10"
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1328811
comments.author: halber_mensch

comments.text: "PETG" plastic? where did you get that nice translucent blue?
comments.author: Peterthinks

comments.text: I bought a roll of blue & a roll of yellow from http://intservo.com/products/esun-petg-filament-1-75mm-1kg-spool?variant=963056455 I have been printing this at 235C.
comments.author: Peterthinks

comments.text: Thanks GeoDave!
comments.author: GeoDave
